Below Basic: A 14-year-old boy has pain in his right knee that got worse after one month. He walks 1 mile every day and does not take medicine for pain. He broke his right leg when he was 8. He has asthma and uses inhalers. His mother has diabetes, and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is 170 cm tall and weighs 88 kg. His skin at the neck is thick and dark. His right hip is sore and hard to move. What in his past causes this condition?

His mother has diabetes, and his grandmother has osteoporosis. His height is 170 cm and weight is 88 kg, with thick skin on his neck. His right hip is painful and stiff. What in his history raised his risk for this condition?

His mother has diabetes, and his grandmother has osteoporosis. His height is 170 cm and weight is 88 kg, with thick, dark skin on his neck. Right hip tenderness and limited motion are noted. Based on his history, what most increased his risk for this condition?

His anthropometrics show a height of 170 cm, a weight of 88 kg, and noticeable hyperpigmented, thickened skin at the neck. His right hip examination reveals tenderness and restricted range of motion. Given this patient's history, which factor most significantly increased his risk for this condition?

Below Basic: A 32-year-old man visits the office because he has coughed up a little blood for 1 day. He has had breathing trouble and swollen ankles for 2 days. For 2 weeks, he has felt more and more tired and has dark urine sometimes. He is usually healthy and doesn't take any medicine. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90 beats per minute, respirations are 18 breaths per minute, and blood pressure is 175/110 mm Hg. His oxygen level is 91% on room air. Doctors hear crackles in his lungs. Both ankles have 2+ pitting edema. Lab results show: Hemoglobin is 8.9 g/dL, Hematocrit is 27%, Urea nitrogen is 55 mg/dL, Creatinine is 2.9 mg/dL, and Urine has 20–40 RBCs per high power field. Urinalysis shows some different-shaped RBCs and rare RBC casts. A kidney biopsy shows crescentic glomerulonephritis and IgG lining the glomerular capillaries. Which antigens do this patient's antibodies most likely target?

His temperature stands at 37°C (98.6°F), pulse at 90/min, respirations at 18/min, with blood pressure reading 175/110 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation with room air is 91%. Examination reveals diffuse inspiratory crackles over all lung bases. There is 2+ pitting edema of both ankles. Laboratory results are: Hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL, Hematocrit 27%, Serum urea nitrogen 55 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.9 mg/dL, Urine RBC 20–40/hpf. Urinalysis shows some dysmorphic RBCs and rare RBC casts. Kidney biopsy examination reveals crescentic glomerulonephritis and linear IgG deposition along the glomerular capillaries. Against which antigens are this patient's antibodies most likely directed?

What antigens are likely targeted by this patient's antibodies?

A renal biopsy demonstrates crescentic glomerulonephritis with linear IgG deposition along glomerular capillaries. Which antigens are the most likely targets of this patient's antibodies?
